Because of the complex and abstract nature of love, discourse on love is commonly reduced to a [[thought-terminating cliché]], and there are a number of common [[proverb]]s regarding love, from [[Virgil|Virgil's]] "[[Amor Vincit Omnia (Caravaggio)|Love conquers all]]" to the [[The Beatles|Beatles']] "[[All You Need is Love|All you need is love]]." [[Bertrand Russell]] describes love as a condition of "absolute value," as opposed to [[relative value (economics)|relative value]]. Philosopher [[Gottfried Leibniz]] said that love is "to be delighted by the happiness of another."<ref>{{cite web
+
Because of the complex and abstract nature of love, discourse on love is commonly reduced to a [[thought-terminating cliché]], and there are a number of common [[proverb]]s regarding love, from [[Virgil|Virgil's]] "[[Amor Vincit Omnia (Caravaggio)|Love conquers all]]" to the [[The Beatles|Beatles']] "[[All You Need is Love|All you need is love]]." [[St. Thomas Aquinas]], following [[Aristotle]], defines love as "to will the good of another."<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2026.htm#article4 St. Thomas Aquinas, STh I-II, 26, 4, corp. art.]</ref> [[Bertrand Russell]] describes love as a condition of "absolute value," as opposed to [[relative value (economics)|relative value]]. Philosopher [[Gottfried Leibniz]] said that love is "to be delighted by the happiness of another."<ref>{{cite web
